content.body: async/await isn't about hiding promises. It's about taking continuation passing style code and allowing you to write it as linear code so that you can maintain the benefit of existing control flow constructs like `continue`/`break`/`return`/`yield`.
content.formatted_body: async/await isn't about hiding promises. It's about taking continuation passing style code and allowing you to write it as linear code so that you can maintain the benefit of existing control flow constructs like continue/break/return/yield.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: async/await isn't about hiding promises. It's about taking continuation passing style code and allowing you to write it as linear code so that you can maintain the benefit of existing control flow constructs like `continue`/`break`/`return`/`yield`.

async/await isn't about hiding promises. It's about taking continuation passing style code and allowing you to write it as linear code so that you can maintain the benefit of existing control flow constructs like continue/break/return/yield.

content.body:
> <@bakkot:matrix.org> `await.all [a, b, c]` just doesn't seem that different from `await Promise.all([a, b, c])` to me

sure, i do the latter all the time, but in my experience devs in fact consider those quite different, and avoid the latter in favor of `await a; await b; await c` *constantly*

content.formatted_body:
I'm curious if DisposableStack can help here, either:

const { proxy, revoke } = Proxy.revocable(...);
stack.defer(revoke);
return proxy;

// later

stack.dispose(); // mass revocation

Or make the return value of Proxy.revocable itself a disposable.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body:
I'm curious if DisposableStack can help here, either:

const { proxy, revoke } = Proxy.revocable(...);
stack.defer(revoke);
return proxy;

// later

stack.dispose(); // mass revocation

Or make the return value of Proxy.revocable itself a disposable.

content.formatted_body:
const disposable = new DisposableStack()
function createProxy() {
    const {proxy, revoke} = Proxy.revocable(...)
    disposable.defer(revoke)
    return proxy
    // at this point, revoke only hold by the DisposableStack.
    // engine can GC `revoke` and knowing the Proxy is being revoked after the DisposableStack disposes
}

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body:
const disposable = new DisposableStack()
function createProxy() {
    const {proxy, revoke} = Proxy.revocable(...)
    disposable.defer(revoke)
    return proxy
    // at this point, revoke only hold by the DisposableStack.
    // engine can GC `revoke` and knowing the Proxy is being revoked after the DisposableStack disposes
}

content.body:
> <@jackworks:matrix.org> ```js
> const disposable = new DisposableStack()
> function createProxy() {
>     const {proxy, revoke} = Proxy.revocable(...)
>     disposable.defer(revoke)
>     return proxy
>     // at this point, revoke only hold by the DisposableStack.
>     // engine can GC `revoke` and knowing the Proxy is being revoked after the DisposableStack disposes
> }
> ```

I mean, something like `new Proxy(target, handlers, { revocationStack: disposables })` might be feasible, but prefer this approach in general

    return proxy

const disposable = new DisposableStack()
function createProxy() {
    const {proxy, revoke} = Proxy.revocable(...)
    disposable.defer(revoke)
    return proxy
    // at this point, revoke only hold by the DisposableStack.

content.body: I missed a key point in my presentation:  when we revoke a proxy, the _underlying slots_ are nullified, but the _proxy itself_ remains part of the object graph it lives in.  You can't do anything with the proxy, but it's still there because (probably) something else refers to it.  The revocation of an object graph, and of proxies pointing to it, means the original objects in that object graph can be gc'd.  The proxies themselves are still reachable
